title: Riemann's paradox: pi = infinity minus infinity

multiple-choice.question: Who is the famous mathematician that came up with the Riemann rearrangement theorem?
What is the sum of the infinite series 1 - 1/2 + 1/3 - 1/4 + 1/5, ...?
What happens when you rearrange the terms of an infinite series?

options.label: A
options.text: The sum always remains the same

multiple-choice.question: What is the Riemann rearrangement theorem?

options.label: A
options.text: A theorem that states that the sum of an infinite series is always unique

options.label: B
options.text: A theorem that states that the sum of an infinite series can be changed by rearranging the terms

options.label: C
options.text: A theorem that states that an infinite series can be rearranged to converge to any sum

options.label: D
options.text: A theorem that states that an infinite series can be rearranged to diverge

multiple-choice.question: What type of series can be rearranged to converge to any sum?

options.label: A
options.text: Convergent series with positive terms adding up to ∞ and negative terms adding up to -∞

options.label: C
options.text: Convergent series with positive terms adding up to a finite number and negative terms adding up to a finite number

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you bracket a convergent infinite series?
What is an example of a divergent series that can be bracketed to converge to different sums?
How many different sums can an infinite series be rearranged to?

options.label: C
options.text: Three different cases: no sum, any sum, or one sum

options.label: D
options.text: Two different cases: convergent or divergent

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition for an infinite series to be rearranged to converge to any sum?

options.label: A
options.text: The positive terms add up to ∞ and the negative terms add up to -∞

options.label: B
options.text: The positive terms add up to a finite number and the negative terms add up to a finite number

title: How far can we go?
